author: m.kalinin
content:
1) Consensus Upgrade
2) `Eth1Data` follow distance cut
3) BEACONBLOCKROOT opcode
4) Validator withdrawals
5) Merge chains (app with beacon)

1+2 can go together as 2) doesn't seem that complex and involves only beacon chain work but this is not yet decided. 

It would make sense to deploy 3+4 at once

This is a rough change set. 5) is the "full" merge but it requires a layer that will provide the application chain history beyond WS period; and it also requires application JSON-RPC changes. This is why it's that complicated and we don't want it to go with the consensus upgrade.

author: m.kalinin
content: To be more precise, executable beacon chain was not explicit about the 5) but it was implied in the time of the origin proposal. After the R&D workshop, merging two chains was re-visited with the decision to decouple it from consensus upgrade and propose separately for the sake of simplicity and to make core developers' and researchers' lives easier.

author: m.kalinin
content:
<@!301186049323958275> regarding the specs for the application layer. The draft of a highlevel spec for consensus part is here, https://hackmd.io/@n0ble/eth1-eth2-communication-protocol-draft. It should be purified and adjusted to consensus upgrade needs, i.e. block roots should be removed as EVM does not expose them.

It does not include block gossip deprecation, state and full sync adjustments, simply speaking does not cover the network part of the application layer.

And there are might be huge changes behind each method of this simple RPC in the modern clients. `setHead` implies that fork choice and block storage based on difficulty are deprecated and should undergo corresponding changes which could be pretty big. Block production doesn't require much I think as `getWork` is already exposed. Block import means removing any consensus validation e.g. ethash, difficulty, time restrictions.

author: m.kalinin
content:
The work on merging the chains will start after the consensus upgrade. Keeping two chains is redundant and it makes sense to have only one chain, the beacon chain and the application layer to manage the state and be stripped down to state transition function only. Even transaction pool may sit in the beacon chain network. 

But it would require a work on the history data retrieval and JSON-RPC upgrade. Also, plans on scaling execution on L1 would also be an input to merging the chains problem. Probably removing some components would not be needed if application layer will be moved to a shard further.

author: m.kalinin
content:
My assumption is that Infura will receive all the blocks from the network very fast and will import them and verify the execution. It should be relatively easy for Infura to expose a method that would return `true/false` for already imported block; it could be done by exploiting `eth_getBlockByHash` at the moment but it doesn't allow to pass a block which would be needed if for some case the block hasn't been received by Infura before the request for validity.

Block production is more complicated. If a service will keep all the transaction fees then the proposer will be incentivised to propose an empty application payload rather than initiating a roundtrip with the service. Therefore, there is a need of the model which would allow to pay a portion of fees to the proposer.
